Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the situation by stating that the first 7 children who received the COVID-19 vaccine in Senegal died on the spot, which is not supported by evidence.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the statement that mass vaccination for COVID-19 in Senegal started on a specific date and resulted in the death of 7 children.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the deaths of the children were directly caused by the COVID-19 vaccine, without considering other possible factors or explanations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there are no mass vaccinations happening in Africa causing children to die from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider the alternative explanation provided by Alassane Mbodji, who stated that no one died from any vaccine and that the children are healthy.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on misinformation from a video post on Facebook, which was flagged as false news and misinformation.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in this claim.
